doc/source/2002.rst.message: I'm not clear why we're pointing this out. There are many charms that currently do not support policy.d overrides. Is it because Swift will *never* have support?
Swift is a charm that could support policy.d overrides but that support hasn't been added.  It's also one that was asked for (via field support).  This explains why it isn't available.

It's not clear why we need to point out that Cinder and Glance support overrides. We should say why or just leave out this note.

If we do include the note, please use standard format:

.. note::

cinder, glance and swift-proxy are all related charms in terms of "storing things".  swift is an S3 style object storage system.  cinder is a block storage system for nova, that can use swift to store blocks (i.e. file systems), and glance is an image store which can also use cinder.  Thus block and image storage can be controlled using policy.d for tenants/other admin users, but the raw object storage can't be.  This may not be useful, so I'll drop the note.

cinder/image/accelerators/gzip.py.message: This is very confusing.  You are using the srcgz name to be dest +.gz, but then you move that to dest.  So don't you end up with an image that doesn't have .gz on it?

Let me explain it.
We do the compression in a middle level between Glance and Cinder. It is transparent to Glance service. And this is through 'gzip' command.

But while we use 'gzip' to do compression like 'gzip -k A', which means to compress file **A**, file **A.gz** will be produced. And 'gzip' command provide no option to specify the output filename exactly. And Glance service upload file **A**, not file **A.gz**.

We are not intended to impact previous code for image uploading service. So here we take one more step to remove the suffix.

---

We have revised these lines to make them more readable.

Not sure if it matters here, but this will start the stack trace here; if you simply 'raise' with no argument, the stack trace will be from where the exception originated.  (Same thing at lines 50, 60, and 67.)

Also, I suggest adding a comment here and then moving line 37  and line 39 down before the 'try' at line 46.  The comment would say something like: Gzip compresses a file in-place and adds a .gz extension to the filename, so we rename the compressed file back to the name Cinder expects it to have.

We think it will be both okay on 'raise' and 'raise ex'. Stack trace will provide enough for debug I think. But still modified to 'raise'.

Comments added to make it more clear

I think you meant "rename" here?  The problem isn't that there's an extra file left over, it's that now we have a file that doesn't have the name that cinder expects it to have.  Since you know what the filename is, it might be worth including its name in the message.

Probably a good idea to add a comment like: Gzip expects a compressed file to have a .gz extension, so we rename the file before calling Gzip.  Gzip will rename the file to its original name (without the extension) automatically.

I think this is a little misleading.  I think your point that you've introduced a general framework to accommodate hardware compression accelerators, but the only accelerator supported in this release is Intel QuickAssist Technology (QAT), which produces a compressed file in gzip format.  Additionally, the framework provides software-based compression if a suitable hardware accelerator is not available.  Because this software fallback could cause performance problems if the Cinder services are not deployed on sufficiently powerful nodes, the default setting is *not* to enable compressed image uploads.

This also sounds like more of a Glance concern.  I think the point you want to make here is:

In the Image service, the ``compressed`` container format identifier does not indicate a particular compression technology; it is up to the image consumer to determine what compression has been used, and there is no requirement that OpenStack services must support arbitrary compression technologies.  For the upload and download of compressed images, Cinder supports *only* the gzip format.

scripts/glance-simplestreams-sync.py.message:
The description of the configuration option says the input should be a YAML-formatted string.

There is no validation nor conversion taking place that would actually allow you to pass this string to the dictionary update() method.

An alternative to YAML-formatted string could be a string containing a space- or comma- delimited list (check what other configuration options in this charm uses as delimiter for consistency) of key=value pairs which you can validate and parse into a suitable data structure.

I'd probably name the class "GlanceMirrorWithCustomProperties" to make it really clear about what it's doing.

Secondly, I'd pass in the custom_properties as it's own parameter so that the super call to __init__() doesn't contain it.  i.e. something like (which is for python2.7 support as it doesn't support named args before **kwargs):

    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        ...
        custom_properties = kwargs.pop('custom_properties')
        super(GlanceMirrorWithCustomProperties, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.custom_properties = custom_properties

This makes it more resilient to changes in GlanceMirror class.

Again, I'd make this less sensitive to changes in GlanceMirror, and do this instead:

    def prepare_glance_arguments(self, *args, **kwargs):
        glance_args = super(...).prepare_glance_arguments(*args, **kwargs)
        ... etc

Bare excepts are not useful; this is papering over a failure.  Much better to bail out now if the config file couldn't be read or re-throw the error so a higher function can handle it.  This will just cause maintenance issues down the line.

See suggestion above about passing it into the subclassed GlanceMirror directly so that it's doesn't get inadvertently passed to GlanceMirror by accident (which could cause maintenance issues in the future if GlanceMirror changes (for example)).

These checks should be done in the get_conf() function.  Essentially, by swallowing the exception in get_conf() and returning empty dictionaries the context/semantics of the error have been lost.  It's better to perform this error checking as close to the 'getting' as possible, especially as the solution is simply to sys.exit out of the script.  I would catch the error in get_conf with "except Exception as e" and log the actual error as well as the additional checks here (but put them in get_conf).

The get_conf() actually does what it says: it's gets the 'good' configuration data.  incidentally, other functions can still fail (e.g. juju_run_cmd()) if 'unit_name' is not in the id_conf, for example.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Isn't this a security problem?

Say I have a daemon that runs with a ulimit RLIMIT_NOFILE (2048, 4096) and I have 2048 files open.  Then I call a rootwrap process with rlimit_nofile=1024.  won't fd's 1025..2048 get left open in the child?

As rlimit_nofile isn't tied in any way to the process ulimt it'd be trivial for an operator to bump the latter and not the former.

Yes, in this scenario the fds 1025..2048 will get left open in the child. From my perspective passing a fd (that was opened by an unprivileged process like e.g. nova-compute) to a root running process is annoying but not a security problem (it would be worse in the opposite case, where a fd that is maybe only accessible by root would be leaked to non-root). a root process might be able to look at any fd on the system anyway, no matter where it is or where it is going to.

we can improve the documentation to say that one should not have too high of a fd limit set by default to not do this change, or backport a linux specific way of closing the fds more efficiently. I can do that as a new commit to master. 

Please note that the backport is effectively a noop right now so it doesn't make the situation any different by *default*. 

Regarding the daemon mode - in daemon mode the "subprocess.Popen(..., close_fds=True)" is called by every command that is executed by the daemon-mode process, so the performance overhead also exists there. daemon mode optimizes away the startup cost of the python interpreter and the regexp/parsing overhead of the filters, but everything else remains the same.

nova/compute/api.py.message: This all looks good, just not sure about the log levels. I had thought we usually use "warning" to mean the operator should take action and there is no action the operator needs to take here. I would tend to think all should be at debug level, but maybe others would have a different opinion.

Yeah that's a fair point, would INFO also be too high?

I'm happy to drop these down to DEBUG either way tbh but I'll wait to see what others think.

This happened back in like grizzly or havana. I've always thought it's kind of dumb that the bdm is created in compute during the blocking call. Why not just add an optional bdm parameter to the reserve_block_device_name rpc method, change the behavior on the server side if it gets the parameter, meaning the compute is (1) new enough and (2) compute rpc api is not pinned for a rolling upgrade, and then the API can determine if it can create the bdm in the API and send it down to the compute and if there is an error we destroy it up here. Note that would not be a backportable change since it would involve a new RPC API version.
Here is a WIP for this https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692940/.

Agree that this is best resolved by a different approach, e.g. this one.

Agree that a backportable approach is also required.

This is a race, and one which I suspect we will normally hit in practise, meaning this won't fix the issue. Lets assume that the reason this occurred is because of bug 1840912. We don't *have* to assume this, btw. This race could occur any other way, but I wouldn't be surprised to discover that in practise this was the underlying issue, and it is certainly an actual bug which would cause this issue and trigger this race.

If that happens, the sequence of events is:

COMPUTE:

blocking_libvirt_call()

API:

reserve_block_device_name()

RABBIT:

queue reserve_block_device_name() for compute, which doesn't pick it up because it's frozen

API:

timeout
Look for bdm to clean up
Don't find any, do nothing

COMPUTE:

blocking_libvirt_call() completes
Receive reserve_block_device_name from message queue
Create BDM

... and the BDM has still been left lying around ...

The same race would also occur if something on the compute host was holding the instance lock for a long time. In that case rabbit would deliver the message immediately, but it would still timeout before the compute host created the BDM, which it eventually would.

The same race could also occur if rabbit was being slow delivering messages, or if the compute was slow to respond for any other reason, e.g. slow libvirt calls, storage issues, excessive load, etc.

Well I'm speculating as to the actual cause, but that very specific sequence is pretty much deterministic if the compute is frozen. My point is that in the presence of the libvirt proxy calls bug, this is exactly what we would expect to see. Given that we've seen several of those downstream now, and it was a timeout, it's not at all unlikely. Certainly that bug would result in this one.

As noted there are also several other potential practical triggers of this race. In fact, I suggest that most things that would trigger this bug would also trigger this race.

My -1 is because I think it's confusing to add this code which I suspect will rarely fix the bug in question if the compute call timed out, which it did in this case.

Even if we hit that very specific sequence we're no worse off than we are now, right? Meaning the API tries to delete a bdm which doesn't exist and the compute creates one which gets orphaned - but that's already the end state we're in today right? IOW, Lee's "fix" here is a best effort attempt at cleaning up not knowing what might have blown up in compute, e.g. maybe we created the bdm and then something else failed.

I would buy the instance lock causing the messaging timeout - we could workaround that by making reserve_block_device_name using the long_rpc_timeout config, right?
Would be nice if these debug messages had instance=instance. Is it possible that some of the error conditions that got us here could blow that up?

oslo_limit/opts.py.message: It is difficult for config management tools to use IDs in config, can we change this to a name?
Reading my old comment it seems I was on board with that. I would say let's go with region and service and if we find a more elegant way to do this later we can always switch.
Interesting. I'm curious if others have thoughts on if there is a way to make that a little better.

One observation on Colleen's deployment flow is that I don't think this wouldn't require a keystone restart. It would be set on the other service's (nova, cinder, etc.) side, so as long as keystone is up before the other services are deployed (which I think is normally the case), the deployment tool could query keystone for this id before it generates the service's config. Which is still added complexity, but not _quite_ as bad as having to do multiple restarts.

Region and service name would be easier to statically configure though. Any deployment tool should have those values easily available.

Hmm, I guess it makes sense from that perspective.

Config management tools are often not great at orchestrating their run in such a way that they can know the ID of a resource at the time they are creating config files. This is what would need to happen to set this endpoint ID in keystone.conf:

1. keystone.conf needs to exist with some basic config to start with
2. db sync/bootstrap happens
3. keystone service is started
4. endpoint gets created in keystone through the API
5. API request to get the ID of the endpoint
6. update keystone.conf with the ID
7. restart the keystone service

With declarative systems like puppet or chef, changing keystone.conf after it's already set is tricky. For all config management systems, having to restart the keystone service more than once is a problem.

We don't have to solve this in this patch, I just happened to notice it here since I didn't review the original change.

So... I think colleen is right here, region and service type are what we want here.

If we think about fast forward upgrade, we (the config management) already know the service type and region, as we created the endpoint in the first place. But we never bothered making a note of the service ID, but in skip level, the API is off, so there is no way to fetch the service ID... it all gets very complicated.

Kolla-ansible creates the endpoints here, as an example:
https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/master/ansible/roles/service-ks-register/tasks/main.yml

Why is that? Endpoints don't have a name. If we were to do this, we'd probably need to include parameters for region and service.

I want to say I vaguely remember that getting brought up in the initial design and people suggested using endpoint instead of region+service so operators only needed to set one thing instead of two. I could be wrong, it's been a while.
Are we going to switch from endpoint_id to region/service as a followup? It seems like we're all in agreement that id is non-optimal for deployment tools.
yes, although I didn't want to distract from these bits that are blocking development. I should do that patch soon.

neutron/db/migration/alembic_migrations/.message:
Can we make the logic here a bit smarter and check if those tables exist in the database first before attempting to create it ?

Otherwise people migrating from networking-ovn to neutron ovn will bump into:

2019-11-26 20:52:52.221556 | controller | pymysql.err.InternalError: (1050, "Table 'ovn_revision_numbers' already exists")

Oh right, ok... The ovn job (in neutron) is currently failing with the error I've just copy and pasted.

Maybe we will need to make it non-voting while we migrate the code ?

We do not have that logic to skip creating the tables if they already exist there.

This logic in implemented in L40.

If you try to execute manually "neutron-db-manage upgrade heads", this script will also try to apply networking-ovn heads and this create this clash. If you skip networking-ovn (from this point won't be needed), the migration is done correctly.

This is how it is done now in networking-ovn. And because of that we should stay with this like that here and maybe add follow up patch with another db migration which will set properly default value on db level.

If we will change it now we will end up with 2 different db schemas in Ussur.

1. Deployment on Train with installed networking-ovn already, so in database there is ovn_revision_numbers table without default value set. Our script checks that table already exists so will do nothing and on Ussuri in db there will be still no default value,

2. New deployment or deployment on Train without networking-ovn installed. This alembic script will check that ovn_revision_number don't exists so it will create it from scratch. If we will set here "server_default" instead of "default" than in db on Ussuri we will have set default value for this column.

We should be really careful and avoid any of such differences between db schema in those 2 variants so lets do it now like it is, even if it's wrong and than propose follow-up patch with another db upgrade script to fix it.

You are right, we need to keep synchronized the DB schema, regardless of the path taken (new installation or upgrade from networking-ovn).

To have this default value in "revision_number" in the existing tables, I'll add the needed code to alter this field.

This value (and the other ones), do not have a DB backend enforced value, but can't be False.

By default, when a Python model object is created, the default value assigned to this object will be the current time. If the python code does NOT pass a value in this field, the DB backend will complain.

doc/source/specs/stx-4.0/approved/contai.message:
... just a question:

Upgrades between major versions of kubernetes would not be possible with the procedure described in this doc ?

Upgrades between major versions of kubernetes will be possible as part of future overall StarlingX upgrade procedure ?
There is no upgrade procedure for a new major release. Until they release a new major release (if they ever do), we won't know how (or if) we would do that kind of upgrade.
is this duplicated line?
No - this use case is for a minor version - the previous one is for a patch version.
does this version means current deployed version ? or new version ? it is vague to use 'this version'
"This version" refers to the "version" value on the previous line. For example 1.16.1. It is not the currently deployed version or a new version. It is "this version" in the metadata.
nit: suggest "software patches"
Done
nit: spaces instead of tabs?
Done
"This is results in" ... also appears a few sections below
Done

*shall we consider abort action ?
*is there timeout mechanism ?

Kubernetes does not support downgrading from one minor version to another, so in many cases an abort would not be possible. It may be possible to abort a patch version upgrade, but that will be left for a future story as it could be a significant amount of effort.
will impart dist-cloud scenario?

That is a good question. In this story, the each subcloud would be upgraded in the same way as a standard system, so code changes shouldn't be required. However, we should test it, so I will add it to the list.
But those patches will be installed in the upgrade process, right?
Sure, thanks
Correct - as part of the upgrade process, the user will install the patches. You can see that in step 13 (for example) in the procedure below.

Regarding application health checks: the default platform apps (platform-integ-app, which also provisions storage), may need to be updated to utilize new kubernetes APIs in case of deprecation.  A mechanism (plugins) may need to be provided for general apps to be checked for the versions supported prior to upgrade.

Agreed. That is discussed in the following spec:
https://docs.starlingx.io/specs/specs/stx-3.0/approved/containerization-2006537-decoupling-container-apps.html
Do we also need final health after the upgrade completely done?
Great, thanks
The health checks will be done when running the various upgrade CLIs. After the upgrade is done, the user can run our health check CLIs and alarms will be raised for significant system issues.

May be we should also mention the need to have a sushy OEM extension package installed on the system for requested OEM object to be handled. In other words, for this script to work two things are required: (1) Redfish BMC to include OEM piece in the requested resource for specific vendor and (2) sushy OEM extension package installed on the system for the same vendor.

You may want to check the code (get_oem_extension) to see for yourself how it works and the exact requirements for the whole thing to succeed.

includes
This holds true for all resources and vendors regardless OEM extension presence. So you always need searching, your search may or may not succeed.

Good point, though, may be we should note that presently neither of the emulators (static/dynamic) readily expose any OEM. So for the user to run the above mentioned example, they would probably need to manually add some OEM resource to emulators' templates. Perhaps it's easier with static emulator.

You can't ensure the presence of vendor extension on the server by changing your client query, right? The server either serves OEM branch for a resource to the clients or not. If it does not, then this example script won't work and the client can't do anything about that.

Once you have BMC that serves OEM extension for a resource, the client can search for it by vendor ID. This search might succeed if OEM branch is in place.

I'd suggest you going through sushy code to have a clear picture of how this OEM lookup works (get_oem_extension), then express the logic behind that in English. Reading Redfish OEM spec can also be revealing.

Please, follow established style of sushy documentation. Also, may be running some sort of a linter on the docs you push would improve the quality of the patches you propose.

Another advice would be to code-review your own patches first. These typos and malformed formatting is not something your fellow code reviewers would crave for.

nova/scheduler/host_manager.py.message:
We could optimize by filtering out any compute nodes where free_disk_gb is null in the DB API query here. But really this is a weird race to hit in the scheduler between the time the compute node resource provider is reported to placement and the resource tracker updates the compute node record in the DB (unless the stale node is getting cached somehow in the scheduler?).

Tracing the compute node creation and update and stuff in the resource tracker, the node is created in the DB here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L595

note that at this point the free_disk_gb field isn't set, that gets set later here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1036

And _update_usage looks like it's only called during claims and when periodically updating resource usage for instances and migrations on the host, which wouldn't be anything on a new compute. But then how do we ever use this compute if HostManager._update_from_compute_node requires free_disk_gb to be set? Oh it looks like RT _update_usage_from_instances will set the field even if there aren't any instances on the host:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1259

That's pretty dumb - that should probably be handled in ComputeNode.update_from_virt_driver or something outside of _update_usage_from_instances. Anyway, we should then save those changes off here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1010

We'll create the resource provider here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L948

then report the provider inventory to placement here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L996

which is how it can become an allocation candidate for the scheduler.

Anyway, looking at the RT code the compute node record should have free_disk_gb set before the resource provider is created in placement and updated with inventory so it's a bit puzzling how we could even get here, unless maybe the compute nodes table save failed but the placement resource provider create and inventory update didn't...(this host is overloaded that I'm testing on and I'm hitting db connection failures).

Failing ComputeNode.save() should actually blow up the update_available_resource call before we hit placement though so I'm still not sure how this is happening but I've a node in the DB with null free_disk_gb:

mysql> select host,uuid from compute_nodes where free_disk_gb is NULL;
+------------+--------------------------------------+
| host       | uuid                                 |
+------------+--------------------------------------+
| devstack34 | a251bacf-9d6a-4ad3-abfb-f723c491e857 |
+------------+--------------------------------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

and there is a resource provider for that node:

stack@devstack:~$ openstack resource provider show a251bacf-9d6a-4ad3-abfb-f723c491e857
+------------+--------------------------------------+
| Field      | Value                                |
+------------+--------------------------------------+
| uuid       | a251bacf-9d6a-4ad3-abfb-f723c491e857 |
| name       | devstack34                           |
| generation | 2                                    |
+------------+--------------------------------------+

Yup the ComputeNode.save() to the DB blew up:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/753578/

But then how/when does the resource provider get created?

Ah, a later update_available_resource run creates the provider:

Jun 28 19:20:59 devstack nova-compute[13597]: INFO nova.scheduler.client.report [None req-d49821a3-a69a-42e7-a8d1-67da58e89a71 None None] [req-3ce3b7d4-d127-4ca8-a559-c57226fc0294] Created resource provider record via placement API for resource provider with  UUID a251bacf-9d6a-4ad3-abfb-f723c491e857 and name devstack34.

And that's probably because we updated RT.old_resources before:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L908

Then ComputeNode.save() failed so we didn't create the provider, then on the next update_available_resource run we finally got past this:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/324da0532f3b59aa16233a93a260d289e55860fb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1005

Because it didn't think there were any changes and then created the provider.

That's pretty messy...we should probably rollback the changes to RT.old_resources if we can't update the ComputeNode. That's likely a separate patch though.
Created separate bug 1834712 for the RT issue.

So I was thinking, we should just do:

if host_state.updated:
    seen_nodes.add(state_key)

here, because HostState.updated is None on init and _update_from_compute_node will return before setting self.updated if free_disk_gb is not set in the ComputeNode. That's probably the cleaner fix than the whack-a-mole thing I'm doing here and in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668243/, though https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668243/ is pretty straight-forward on its own.

Making the change to check for host_state.updated here makes some unit tests fail and it's not trivial (at least with my Friday brain) to fix them, but it's probably the cleaner thing to do.
I don't think update here is better.

> Surely the allocation ratios can't be the only thing that'll go kablooey in that case?

Right, we know failed_builds was another one. Hence the TODO below, which when I tried locally on Friday that caused some unit tests to fail which weren't easy to fix, but I'll probably change this patch to implement that TODO instead.

There is also this:

https://review.opendev.org/668263

It makes sense to me to set these before the early-bailout check below, assuming they're available...

...but I guess I'm more concerned that something is trying to use them in the first place if the compute service isn't fully ready yet. Surely the allocation ratios can't be the only thing that'll go kablooey in that case?

nit: Either add a comma here or move the closing parenthesis up.

The pros of having the closing parenthesis on the next line is that if we add more arguments here there is a smaller diff, but that mandates the last argument having a comma (',') behind it, otherwise we would get just a large diff by adding the comma before the next argument.

The pros of having the closing parenthesis just after and on the same line of the last argument is that it looks more compact.

I've been thinking about this approach recently. The downside is that it generates *so* many tests (1,000+ for keystone alone).

I'm an advocate for robust testing, but my concern is that it will be a high bar for other projects and ultimately prevent them from developing their policies.

Next week we're going to discuss a few different testing options during keystone's office hours (December 3rd).

It looks like with the way the tests use mock to patch out the function call, they won't be as expensive to run as the keystone tests are.

Keystone also has individual tests for each case (eg. test_system_admin_can_list_users, test_domain_reader_cannot_list_users, test_project_member_cannot_get_user_not_found etc) where these tests put all that functionality under one test, so it seems like the number of tests won't blow up that much.

This is a very black-and-white approach, there might be some times when you want to test not just whether it errors or not but the actual result. Maybe those cases can be special cased and handled separately.

+1, yeah we need to write those tests in a different manner. For exmaple when doing the get-all-tenant servers policy change we need to take care of the response based verification instead of just replying on API operation pass.

nova/utils.py.message:
TypeError: slice indices must be integers or None or have an __index__ method'

so I'll change this to:

    return token[:min(int(len(token) / 2), 8)] + '***'
Sure.  it was done this was to avoid open-coding the '***' twice but you could micro-optimise this

That's 8 too many. I understand you were doing this for debug purposes. Instead, take a hash of the real token, and print that. This will a) be more secure and b) not have the possible conflict issue you have here (2 different real tokens that start with same up-to-8 characters)

As noted in patch set 20, that's 8 too many. I understand you were doing this for debug purposes, and agree that we need to do something to make debug possible. But you don't need any real characters to do that. Take a hash of the real token and print that instead of a truncated token. This will a) be more secure and b) not have the possible conflict issue you have here (2 different real tokens that start with same characters). It's also consistent with the approach used to protect tokens in other places.

I think a hash is used to protect the keystone token but in other place simple replacement of part of the token with * characters is used. If we are unlucky enough to get two token that start with the same characters we will have to live with it. In most use cases re trying will address the issue.

I have the same comment as Matthew, while this is better than logging a full token, I had more in mind to hash the token as he suggested. That's how tokens are redacted in novaclient [1] (example: "{SHA1}%s" % sha1) and I thought it's quite nice.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/blob/744c9b6/novaclient/client.py#L261-L295

As I said previously, a hash is used to protect the keystone token because that is a long lived token that we don't want to expose any part of because it allows control of the entire tenant resources. However in other place simple replacement of part of the token with * characters is used so we should be consistent and implement this approach. If we are unlucky enough to get two token that start with the same characters we will have to live with it. In most use cases re trying will address the issue.

this should be "6" in the current changeset. I actually recommend not saying how many characters, so the code speaks for itself and you avoid confusion if someone does what you just did here and updates the code without updating the comment.
Sorry, why would we want to include any part of the real token? AFAIK we should just mask the entire thing and use '***' everywhere.
I don't know why we want parts of the token. I updated the patch to hide the whole token.

So clearly this is some cinder API wrinkle when creating a volume from a snapshot yeah? Because if encryption is not involved then it seems that we don't need to provide a volume type and it's been fine thus far. I only wonder if we might have a problem where this is a behavior change for non-encrypted volume snapshots where the original volume type is gone so we'll now fail the boot from volume due to the volume create failing by specifying a volume type that no longer exists. I think in the non-encrypted volume snapshot case, if a volume type isn't specified cinder will just apply the default volume type correct?

It looks like the volume details include an "encrypted" boolean:

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/?expanded=show-a-volume-s-details-detail#show-a-volume-s-details

Should we only pass the volume_type to volume create if the original snapshot volume was encrypted? Or at least confirm that if the volume type we're about to pass doesn't exist, that we can ignore passing it if the original volume is not encrypted?

nova/virt/block_device.py.message: Per my question in the commit message, should we only pass the volume type if orig_volume['encrypted']?
As discussed I believe this is safe for non-encrypted volumes as we can't delete volume types that are still referenced and also can't delete volumes referenced by snapshots.

Can this raise a 404 if the original volume is gone? Actually I'm not even sure you can delete the original volume if it has snapshots, so likely not an issue. And for that matter, I'm not sure you can delete a volume type while there are volumes using it.

Took a while to track this down but yes by default this fails:

https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/62b69b51aab32500d3aa76677011f9db4bf4c14c/cinder/volume/api.py#L458-L472

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/?expanded=show-a-volume-s-details-detail#show-a-volume-s-details says the parameter is "volume_type" not volume_type_id, so is the API reference wrong or does it also return volume_type_id and that's just not documented (I wouldn't be surprised if the cinder API reference is wrong, I've fixed quite a few things like this in there).

It's actually our own summary translation code in Nova that causes this:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6fea2682364cddf66c499936a8c66895ef94dd5b/nova/volume/cinder.py#L313

OK the API reference is correct:

https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/62b69b51aab32500d3aa76677011f9db4bf4c14c/cinder/api/v2/views/volumes.py#L81

It's us that's weird:
